VERSION.phpdoc:
/**
     * Bolt's version constant.
     *
     * This should take the form of:
     *   x.y.z [[alpha|beta|RC|patch] n]
     *
     * e.g. versions for:
     *   Stable — 3.0.0
     *   Development — 3.1.0 alpha 1
     */

compare.phpdoc:
/**
     * Compares a semantic version (x.y.z) against Bolt's version, given a
     * specified comparison operator.
     *
     * Note 1:
     * Be sure to include the `.z` number in the version given, as
     * omitting it can give inconsistent results.
     *
     * e.g. If the version of Bolt was '3.2.0' (or greater), then:
     *     `Version::compare('3.2', '>=');`
     * is NOT equal to, or greater than, Bolt's version.
     *
     * Note 2:
     * Pre-release versions, such as 3.2.0-beta1, are considered lower
     * than their final release counterparts (like 2.3.0). As you may notice,
     * the difference being that Bolt '3.2.0-beta1' is considered LOWER than
     * the `compare($version)` value of '3.2.0'.
     *
     * e.g. If the version of Bolt was '3.2.0 beta 1', then:
     *     `Version::compare('3.2.0', '>=');`
     * is equal to, or greater than, Bolt's version.
     *
     * @see http://semver.org/ For an explanation on semantic versioning.
     * @see http://php.net/manual/en/function.version-compare.php#refsect1-function.version-compare-notes Notes on version_compare
     *
     * @param string $version the version to compare
     * @param string $operator the comparison operator: <, <=, >, >=, ==, !=
     *
     * @return bool whether the comparison succeeded
     */

installType.phpdoc:
/**
     * Determine the "install type": Whether we're currently running a direct
     * git clone, a composer install project, or a packaged distribution.
     */

/**

PathResolver.phpdoc:
/**
 * A class to resolve and manage paths. Paths defined here are allowed to have variables within them.
 * For example: "files" folder is within the web directory so it is defined as "%web%/files". This allows
 * the web directory to be changed and the files path does not have to be redefined.
 *
 * @author Carson Full <carsonfull@gmail.com>
 */

__construct.phpdoc:
/**
     * @param string $root the root path which must be absolute
     *
     * @throws ConfigurationException
     */

define.phpdoc:
/**
     * Define a path, or really an alias/variable.
     *
     * @throws ConfigurationException
     */

resolve.phpdoc:
/**
     * Resolve a path.
     *
     * Examples:
     *  - `%web%/files` - A path with variables.
     *  - `files` - A previously defined variable.
     *  - `foo/bar` - A relative path that will be resolved against the root path.
     *  - `/tmp` - An absolute path will be returned as is.
     *
     * @param bool $absolute if the path is relative, resolve it against the root path
     *
     * @throws ConfigurationException
     */

get.phpdoc:
/**
     * Get a config value, using a path.

     */

/**

     * in our config folder. This way you can pass in either an absolute
     * filename or simply 'menu.yaml'.
     */

initializeAll.phpdoc:
/**
     * Runs once, invoked from the ExtensionSubscriber, to bootstrap all
     * extensions by injecting the container and running their initialize method
     *
     * @see ExtensionSubscriber::onKernelResponse()
     */

getAllRoutes.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method calls the `getRoutes()` method for all registered extension,
     * and compiles an array of routes. This is used in
     * Bolt\Extension\RoutesLoader::load() to add all these routes to the
     * (cached) routing.
     * The reason why we're not iterating over `$this->extensions` is that when
     * this method is called, they are not instantiated yet.
     */

initialize.phpdoc:
/**
     * Called when initialising the Extension. Use this to register widgets or
     * do other tasks after boot.
     */

getComposerPackage.phpdoc:
/**
     * Get the ComposerPackage, that contains information about the package,
     * version, etc.
     */

injectObjects.phpdoc:
/**
     * Injects commonly used objects into the extension, for use by the
     * extension. Called from the listener.
     *
     * @see ExtensionSubscriber
     */

getService.phpdoc:
/**
     * This bit of code allows us to get services from the container, even if
     * they are not marked public. We need to be able to do this, because we
     * can't anticipate which services an extension's author will want to get,
     * and neither should we want to make them all public. So, we resort to
     * this, regardless of them being private / public. With great power comes
     * great responsibility.
     *
     * Note: We wouldn't have to do this, if we could Autowire services in our
     * own code. If you have good ideas on how to accomplish that, we'd be
     * happy to hear from your ideas.
     *
     * @throws \ReflectionException
     */

$cacheDuration.phpdoc: /** @var int duration (in seconds) to cache output */

     * which can be overridden in a custom Widget or trait

run.phpdoc:
/**

ResponseAwareInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface ResponseAwareInterface - Widgets that make use of the Response to provide
 * their functionality need to implement this interface.
 */

 * Interface StopwatchAwareInterface - Widgets that implement this interface, will have

RequestAwareInterface.phpdoc:
/**

 * their functionality need to implement this interface.
 */

/**

 * this interface, in order to have their contents cached.
 */

/**

 * Twig\Environment and to render a Twig template.
 */

cssTagsAfter.phpdoc:
/**

     */

cssTagsBefore.phpdoc:
/**
     * insert some HTML before the first CSS include in the page.
     * If there is no CSS anywhere, place it right after start of head.
     */

jsTagsBefore.phpdoc:
/**
     * insert some HTML before the first javascript include in the page.
     * If there is no JS anywhere, place it right after start of body.
     */

jsTagsAfter.phpdoc:
/**

     * If there is no JS anywhere, place it right before end of body.

     *     cascade={"persist"}

__call.phpdoc:
/**
     * Generic getter for a record fields. Will return the field with $name.
     *
     * If $name is not found, throw an exception if it's invoked from code, and
     * return null if invoked from within a template. In templates we need to be
     * more lenient, in order to do things like `{% if record.foo %}..{% endif %}
     *
     * Note: We can not rely on `{% if record.foo is defined %}`, because it
     * always returns `true` for object properties.
     * See: https://craftcms.stackexchange.com/questions/2116/twig-is-defined-always-returning-true
     *
     * - {{ record.title }} => field named title
     * - {{ record|title }} => value of guessed title field
     * - {{ record.image }} => field named image
     * - {{ record|image }} => value of guessed image field
     */

convertToLocalFromDatabase.phpdoc:
/**
     * All date/timestamps are stored in the database in UTC. When retrieving
     * them, we get the timestamp as-is in the DB with the current local
     * timezone slapped onto it. This method converts it back to UTC, and
     * then re-applies the current local timezone to it.
     */

 */

$formatConvertRules.phpdoc:
/**
     * This defines the mapping between PHP ICU date format (key) and moment.js date format (value)
     * For ICU formats see http://userguide.icu-project.org/formatparse/datetime#TOC-Date-Time-Format-Syntax
     * For Moment formats see http://momentjs.com/docs/#/displaying/format/.

extractLocations.phpdoc:
/**
     * Find the locations of each of the words.
     * Nothing exciting here. The array_unique is required, unless you decide
     * to make the words unique before passing in.
     */

determineSnipLocation.phpdoc:
/**
     * Work out which is the most relevant portion to display
     * This is done by looping over each match and finding the smallest distance between two found
     * strings. The idea being that the closer the terms are the better match the snippet would be.
     * When checking for matches we only change the location if there is a better match.
     * The only exception is where we have only two matches in which case we just take the
     * first as will be equally distant.
     */

extractRelevant.phpdoc:
/**
     * Center on, and highlight search terms in excerpts.

     * @see: http://www.boyter.org/2013/04/building-a-search-result-extract-generator-in-php/

     * @param string|array $words
     */

SelectQuery.phpdoc:
/**
 *  This query class coordinates a select query build from Bolt's
 *  custom query DSL as documented here:.
 *
 * @see https://docs.bolt.cm/templates/content-fetching
 *
 *  The resulting QueryBuilder object is then passed through to the individual
 *  field handlers where they can perform value transformations.
 *
 * @author Ross Riley <riley.ross@gmail.com>
 */

getWhereExpression.phpdoc:
/**
     * Creates a composite expression that adds all the attached
     * filters individual expressions into a combined one.
     */

getFilters.phpdoc:
/**
     * Returns all the filters attached to the query.
     *
     * @return Filter[]
     */

build.phpdoc:
/**
     * Part of the QueryInterface this turns all the input into a Doctrine
     * QueryBuilder object and is usually run just before query execution.
     * That allows modifications to be made to any of the parameters up until
     * query execution time.
     */

setQueryBuilder.phpdoc:
/**
     * Allows replacing the default QueryBuilder.
     *
     * @param QueryBuilder $qb
     */

processFilters.phpdoc:
/**
     * Internal method that runs the individual key/value input through
     * the QueryParameterParser. This allows complicated expressions to
     * be turned into simple sql expressions.
     *
     * @throws \Exception
     */

/**
 *  Handler class to convert the DSL for content query parameters
 *  into equivalent ORM expressions.
 *
 * @author Ross Riley <riley.ross@gmail.com>
 */

multipleKeyAndValueHandler.phpdoc:
/**
     * This handler processes 'triple pipe' queries as implemented in Bolt
     * It looks for three pipes in the key and value and creates an OR composite
     * expression for example: 'username|||email':'fred|||pete'.
     */

multipleValueHandler.phpdoc:
/**
     * This handler processes multiple value queries as defined in the Bolt 'Fetching Content'
     * documentation. It allows a value to be parsed to and AND/OR expression.
     *
     * For example, this handler will correctly parse values like:
     *     'username': 'fred||bob'
     *     'id': '<5 && !1'
     */

defaultFilterHandler.phpdoc:
/**
     * The default handler is the last to be run and handles simple value parsing.
     *
     * @param string|array $value
     */

parseValue.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method uses the defined value matchers to parse a passed in value.
     *
     * The following component parts will be returned in the array:
     * [
     *     'value' => <the value remaining after the parse>
     *     'operator' => <the operator that should be used>
     *     'matched' => <the pattern that the value matched>
     * ]
     */

addFilterHandler.phpdoc:
/**
     * The goal of this class is to turn any key:value into a Filter class.
     * Adding a handler here will push the new filter callback onto the top
     * of the Queue along with the built in defaults.
     *
     * Note: the callback should either return nothing or an instance of
     * \Bolt\Storage\Filter
     */

addValueMatcher.phpdoc:
/**
     * Adds an additional token to parse for value parameters.
     *
     * This gives the ability to define additional value -> operator matches
     *
     * @param string $token Regex pattern to match against
     * @param array $params Options to provide to the matched param
     * @param bool $priority If set item will be prepended to start of list
     */

     * Internal method that takes the 'query' part of the input and

     * A simple select operation will just contain the ContentType eg 'pages'

parseDirectives.phpdoc:

     * Directives are all of the other parameters supported by Bolt that do not

/**

/**
     * Returns the actual object of the expression. This is generally

getParameters.phpdoc:
/**
     * Returns the array of parameters attached to this filter. These are
     * normally used to replace placeholders at compile time.
     */

getContent.phpdoc:
/**
     * getContent based on a 'human readable query'.
     *
     * Used by the twig command {% setcontent %} but also directly.
     * For reference refer to @see https://docs.bolt.cm/templating/content-fetching
     *
     * @return Pagerfanta|Content|null
     */

getContentForTwig.phpdoc:
/**
     * Helper to be called from Twig that is passed via a TwigRecordsView rather than the raw records.
     *
     * @param string $textQuery The base part like `pages` or `pages/1`
     * @param array $parameters Parameters like `printquery` and `paging`, but also `where` parameters taken from `... where { foo: bar } ...`
     *
     * @return Pagerfanta|Content|null
     */

QueryScopeInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface QueryScopeInterface
 * Interface defines a class that provides additional scoping for a Content Query.
 *
 * @author Ross Riley <riley.ross@gmail.com>
 */

QueryInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface that defines minimum functionality of a Bolt Query class.
 *
 * The goal of a query is to store select and filter parameters that can be
 * used to create a relevant SQL expression.
 */

IdentifiedSelectHandler.phpdoc:
/**
 * Handler to fetch a single record if an identifier is set in the query.
 *
 * @return bool|Content
 */

OrderDirective.phpdoc:
/**
 *  Directive to alter query based on 'order' parameter.
 *
 *  eg: 'pages', ['order'=>'-publishedAt']
 */

setOrderBy.phpdoc:
/**
     * Set the query OrderBy directives
     * given an order (e.g. 'heading', 'id') and direction (ASC|DESC)
     */

showAction.phpdoc:
/**
     * Show an exception. Mainly used for custom 404 pages, otherwise falls back
     * to Symfony's error handling
     */

template.phpdoc:
/**
     * Render a template. Convenient for when we simply wish to render a template as-is. Used as a
     * fallback for the 404 or maintenance pages, for instance.
     *
     * Note: This is _not_ assigned a Route by default. If it were, it's a potential security risk,
     * since a would-be attacker could try to access template files from both the theme and bolt
     * directly.
     */

FrontendZoneInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface FrontendZoneInterface - Frontend Controllers have to implement this
 * interface in order to use the proper widgets for that zone.
 */

logout.phpdoc:
/**
     * This is the route the user can use to logout.
     *
     * But, this will never be executed. Symfony will intercept this first
     * and handle the logout automatically. See logout in config/packages/security.yaml
     *
     * @Route("/logout", name="bolt_logout")
     */

BackendZoneInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface BackendZone - Backend Controllers have to implement this interface
 * in order to use the proper widgets for that zone.
 */

AsyncZoneInterface.phpdoc:
/**
 * Interface AsyncZoneInterface - Async Controllers have to implement this interface in
 * order to use the proper widgets for that zone.
 */

wrapJsonFunction.phpdoc:
/**
     * Prepare a given $where and $slug to be used in a query, depending on
     * whether or not the current platform supports JSON functions
     *
     * For example, wrapJsonFunction('foo', 'bar') gives:
     *
     * Older SQLite, Mysql 5.6 -> [ 'foo', '["bar"]' ]
     * Newer SQLite, Mysql 5.7 -> [ "JSON_EXTRACT(foo, '$[0]')", 'bar' ]
     *
     * @return string|array
     */

hasSQLiteJSONSupport.phpdoc:
/**
     * If we're using SQLite, this method tests for JSON support
     *
     * This query should return `["succes"]` or throw an error if JSON is unsupported.
     * `SELECT JSON_EXTRACT('{"jsonfunctionalitytest":["succes"]}', '$.jsonfunctionalitytest') as value;`
     */

getTablePrefix.phpdoc:
/**
     * Since we introduced `symfony/proxy-manager-bridge`, the keys in the tableprefix
     * no longer match what the manager tells us it should be. For example, the
     * given key was `0000000005ee10ad0000000043b453e3`, but in our reference
     * table we had `0000000005ee10e90000000043b453e3`. We just return the first one, now
     */

JsonExtract.phpdoc:
/**
 * "JSON_EXTRACT" "(" StringPrimary "," StringPrimary {"," StringPrimary }* ")"
 *
 * See: "JSON_EXTRACT: Bolt\Doctrine\Functions\JsonExtract" in `config/packages/doctrine.yaml`
 */

getExtensionRoutesPath.phpdoc:
/**
     * Helper function that returns the path of the extension routes.yaml file
     * inside Bolt.
     */

getExtensionServicesPath.phpdoc:
/**
     * Helper function that returns the path of the extension services.yaml file
     * inside Bolt.
     */

execute.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method is executed after initialize(). It usually contains the logic
     * to execute to complete this command task.
     */

AddUserCommand.phpdoc:
/**
 * A console command that creates users and stores them in the database.
 *
 * To use this command, open a terminal window, enter into your project
 * directory and execute the following:
 *
 *     $ php bin/console app:add-user
 *
 * To output detailed information, increase the command verbosity:
 *
 *     $ php bin/console app:add-user -vv
 *
 * See https://symfony.com/doc/current/cookbook/console/console_command.html
 * For more advanced uses, commands can be defined as services too. See
 * https://symfony.com/doc/current/console/commands_as_services.html
 *
 * @author Javier Eguiluz <javier.eguiluz@gmail.com>
 * @author Yonel Ceruto <yonelceruto@gmail.com>
 */

$defaultName.phpdoc:
/**
     * to make your command lazily loaded, configure the $defaultName static property,
     * so it will be instantiated only when the command is actually called.
     */

initialize.phpdoc:
/**
     * This optional method is the first one executed for a command after configure()
     * and is useful to initialize properties based on the input arguments and options.
     */

interact.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method is executed after initialize() and before execute(). Its purpose
     * is to check if some of the options/arguments are missing and interactively
     * ask the user for those values.
     *
     * This method is completely optional. If you are developing an internal console
     * command, you probably should not implement this method because it requires
     * quite a lot of work. However, if the command is meant to be used by external
     * users, this method is a nice way to fall back and prevent errors.
     */

getCommandHelp.phpdoc:
/**
     * The command help is usually included in the configure() method, but when
     * it's too long, it's better to define a separate method to maintain the
     * code readability.
     */

execute.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method is executed after initialize(). It usually contains the logic
     * to execute to complete this command task.
     */

DeleteUserCommand.phpdoc:
/**
 * A console command that deletes users from the database.
 *
 * To use this command, open a terminal window, enter into your project
 * directory and execute the following:
 *
 *     $ php bin/console app:delete-user
 *
 * Check out the code of the src/App/Command/AddUserCommand.php file for
 * the full explanation about Symfony commands.
 *
 * See https://symfony.com/doc/current/cookbook/console/console_command.html
 * For more advanced uses, commands can be defined as services too. See
 * https://symfony.com/doc/current/console/commands_as_services.html
 *
 * @author Oleg Voronkovich <oleg-voronkovich@yandex.ru>
 */

execute.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method is executed after initialize(). It usually contains the logic
     * to execute to complete this command task.
     */

ListUsersCommand.phpdoc:
/**
 * A console command that lists all the existing users.
 *
 * To use this command, open a terminal window, enter into your project directory
 * and execute the following:
 *
 *     $ php bin/console app:list-users
 *
 * See https://symfony.com/doc/current/cookbook/console/console_command.html
 * For more advanced uses, commands can be defined as services too. See
 * https://symfony.com/doc/current/console/commands_as_services.html
 *
 * @author Javier Eguiluz <javier.eguiluz@gmail.com>
 */

execute.phpdoc:
/**
     * This method is executed after initialize(). It usually contains the logic
     * to execute to complete this command task.
     */

DumpExtension.phpdoc:
/**
 * Dump Twig extension.
 *
 * This is a (deliberately) empty extension. When the implementor switched a
 * site from DEV to PROD, it shouldn't break if there's a lingering `{{ dump }}`
 * left in the site. This Twig Extension acts as a fallback to prevent that.
 */

ArrayExtension.phpdoc:
/**
 * Bolt specific Twig functions and filters that provide array manipulation.
 *
 * @internal
 */

length.phpdoc:
/**
     * Returns the length of a variable.
     * Overrides the default Twig |length filter
     * for accurate results with paginated content
     */

getSortOrder.phpdoc:
/**
     * Get sorting order of name, stripping possible "DESC", "ASC", and also
     * return the sorting order.
     */

SetcontentExtension.phpdoc:
/**
 * Setcontent functionality Twig extension.
 *
 * @author Xiao-Hu Tai <xiao@twokings.nl>
 */

shy.phpdoc:
/**
     * Add 'soft hyphens' ­ to a string, so that it won't break layout in HTML when
     * using strings without spaces or dashes.
     */

absoluteLink.phpdoc:
/**
     * Use relative_path to create a proper link to either a relative page, or
     * to an external source. In the below example, the editor can provide
     * either page/about, or https://boltcms.io, and both will work
     */

getLocales.phpdoc:
/**
     * Takes the list of codes of the locales (languages) enabled in the
     * application and returns an array with the name of each locale written
     * in its own language (e.g. English, Français, Español, etc.).
     */

SetcontentTokenParser.phpdoc:
/**
 * Twig {% setcontent %} token parser.
 *
 * @author Bob den Otter <bob@twokings.nl>
 * @author Xiao-Hu Tai <xiao@twokings.nl>
 */

SetcontentNode.phpdoc:
/**
 * Twig setcontent node.
 *
 * @author Bob den Otter <bob@twokings.nl>
 * @author Ross Riley <riley.ross@gmail.com>
 * @author Xiao-Hu Tai <xiao@twokings.nl>
 */

$tempMap.phpdoc:
/**
     * The temporary map used for one run, when computing everything
     *
     * @var array
     */

$map.phpdoc:
/**
     * The cached map, this holds the results after a computation, also for other classes
     *
     * @var array
     */

UserLocaleSubscriber.phpdoc:
/**
 * Stores the locale of the user in the session after the
 * login. This can be used by the LocaleSubscriber afterwards.
 */
